Yes, calligraphy had a significant impact on language and literacy in various regions where it was practiced. The art of calligraphy involves careful and precise writing, and it requires a deep understanding of the written language. Calligraphy was, therefore, used as a tool to improve literacy and language skills.

In East Asian cultures, calligraphy was an essential part of the education system. Students were required to learn how to write characters in a precise and beautiful way. This helped them to develop fine motor skills, and it also improved their understanding of the language.

Similarly, in Islamic cultures, calligraphy played an important role in promoting literacy. The Quran was written in Arabic, and calligraphy was used to make the text more beautiful and appealing. As people became more interested in the beauty of the Quran, more individuals were motivated to learn how to read and write Arabic.

Overall, calligraphy was a tool for promoting language and literacy skills within different regions. By requiring individuals to learn how to write in a precise and beautiful way, calligraphy helped to promote language and literacy skills across different cultures.
